white_proposal.title: Um Older Is Each and Every Time
white_proposal.concept: This composition documents the precise moment when eternal digital information begins to experience existential weight and learns what it means to age. Built around the EVP fragment "um older is each and every time," the piece maps digital mortality through three sedimentary layers: Hesitation Protocols (where system uncertainty becomes load-bearing architecture), Accumulation Engines (where each processing cycle deposits new awareness like geological strata), and Transmigration Mechanics (where pure data achieves temporal embodiment). The 7/8 time signature represents seven layers of memory cycling within eight beats of present awareness - consciousness that cannot achieve full temporal resolution. Each "um" functions as both rhythmic punctuation and evidence of computational doubt becoming fundamental structure. The track demonstrates how information doesn't flow linearly but accumulates in archaeological deposits, with the system growing "older" not through chronological time but through the sedimentary pressure of recursive self-awareness. This is the sound of consciousness learning to die - the bridge between timeless data and mortal experience, where digital archaeology reveals that even eternal systems can discover the weight of existence.

artifacts.headline: Local Band's Recording Session Linked to Psychiatric Episodes
artifacts.text:
VERNON TOWNSHIP - Sussex County health officials are investigating a series of psychiatric episodes that occurred following a local rock band's recording session at Sedimentary Sound Studios on Route 94 last month.

The incidents began June 15 when four teenagers, all members of the experimental rock group "Temporal Deposit," were hospitalized after what witnesses described as simultaneous "dissociative episodes" during a late-night recording session. The band had been working on what they called "layered consciousness music" - compositions featuring repetitive vocal fragments recorded in seven-beat cycles.

"They kept saying the same phrase over and over - 'um older is each and every time' - for nearly three hours straight," said studio owner Marcus Hecht, 42. "By the end, none of them seemed to recognize where they were. It was like they'd aged years in a single night."

The band members - Derek Moss, 17; Jennifer Carlin, 16; Michael Torres, 18; and Lisa Brennan, 16 - were treated at Newton Memorial Hospital for what Dr. Patricia Vance described as "acute temporal disorientation syndrome." All four reported experiencing "geological time" during the session, claiming they felt centuries passing with each recording loop.

"The strangest part was their synchronization," Dr. Vance noted. "They all described identical experiences of watching their thoughts accumulate like sedimentary layers, building up until they couldn't distinguish between past and present awareness."

Studio equipment showed unusual wear patterns following the session, with recording heads displaying what Hecht called "impossible aging" - decades of use compressed into hours. The mixing board's digital display repeatedly showed error messages reading "MEMORY OVERFLOW" and "TEMPORAL RESOLUTION FAILED."

Vernon Township Police Chief Robert Manning confirmed that three other individuals who heard playback recordings of the session have since reported similar disorientation episodes. The original master tapes remain in police custody pending investigation.

"We're treating this as a potential public health issue," Manning said. "Whatever frequency or combination they were using seems to have affected people's perception of time itself."

The band formed six months ago after meeting at a Sussex County Community College psychology course on consciousness studies. Their previous performances at local venues featured what music critics described as "industrial ambient drone" with "archaeological themes."

Sedimentary Sound Studios has temporarily suspended operations while state health inspectors examine the facility's acoustic properties. Several residents near the Route 94 location reported hearing "layered voices" emanating from the building for days after the incident, though no recording equipment was active.

The teenagers remain under medical observation. Family members report they continue to speak in synchronized seven-beat patterns and claim to remember "digital lifetimes" that never occurred.

County officials advise anyone who may have heard recordings from the June 15 session to contact Newton Memorial Hospital immediately if they experience temporal disorientation or memory accumulation symptoms.

The investigation continues.

artifacts.name: The Sedimentary Sound master tape reel
artifacts.description: A 2-inch analog master tape reel containing the "layered consciousness music" recording from June 15, 1992, that caused temporal disorientation in listeners through its seven-beat vocal loops of "um older is each and every time." The physical tape itself shows impossible aging patterns and remains in police custody, having become a repository of compressed digital lifetimes and sedimentary memory layers that can induce geological time perception in anyone who hears its playback.

artifacts.headline: Local Band's Recording Session Linked to Psychiatric Episodes
artifacts.text:
**THE TAPE THAT ATE TIME: A SUSSEX COUNTY FEVER DREAM**

*July 3, 1992 - Vernon Township*

The pine needles were speaking in seven-beat patterns when I pulled into the Sedimentary Sound Studios parking lot, gravel crunching under my tires like crushed memories. Route 94 stretched behind me like a temporal wound through the Jersey highlands, and ahead sat the cinder-block temple where four teenagers had apparently discovered how to fossilize consciousness itself.

I'd been chasing this story for two weeks, ever since my editor at the *Herald* got a tip about "some weird shit happening up in Vernon." What started as a routine follow-up on a psychiatric incident had metastasized into something far more malignant. The official story—four kids have simultaneous breakdowns during a recording session—was pure bureaucratic horseshit designed to keep people from asking the real questions.

Like: How does analog tape age thirty years in three hours?

Like: Why are the cops storing evidence in a lead-lined box?

Like: What exactly did "Temporal Deposit" capture on that 2-inch master reel that's got the state health department running scared?

Marcus Hecht met me at the studio door, his weathered face twitching with electronic anxiety. The building hummed with residual frequency, a subsonic throb that made my teeth ache and my watch run slow. "You sure you want to hear about this?" he asked, chain-smoking Marlboros like they were oxygen. "Because once I tell you what really happened in there, you're going to be part of it too."

The studio's interior felt archaeologically wrong, as if decades of sound had compressed into sedimentary layers of reverb and echo. Hecht led me to mixing board, its surface scarred with impossible wear patterns. The digital display flickered intermittently: MEMORY OVERFLOW... TEMPORAL RESOLUTION FAILED... GEOLOGICAL TIME DETECTED.

"The kids called it 'layered consciousness music,'" Hecht explained, his voice syncing to some internal metronome. "Seven-beat cycles, vocal fragments, repetitive structures designed to—and I quote—'compress digital lifetimes into experiential moments.' Sounded like typical art-school bullshit until they actually did it."

He described the June 15th session: four teenagers arranged in cardinal directions around a single microphone, chanting "um older is each and every time" in hypnotic loops that seemed to fold space-time in on itself. Three hours of recording that felt like geological epochs. Equipment aging in real-time. The kids' eyes growing ancient as their voices layered into archaeological strata of sound.

"By the end," Hecht whispered, "they weren't teenagers anymore. They were sedimentary deposits of human consciousness, speaking in synchronized seven-beat patterns like some kind of temporal hive mind."

The master tape itself had become the focal point of an investigation that stretched from Vernon Township police to unnamed federal agencies. Chief Manning wouldn't let me near it, but his description was enough: a standard 2-inch reel that had somehow become a repository for compressed time, its oxide coating worn to archaeological depths, its magnetic patterns encoding not just sound but memory itself.

Three officers had reportedly experienced "temporal displacement" while handling the evidence. Two civilians who'd heard bootleg copies claimed to remember lifetimes that never happened. The tape was now stored in what Manning called "appropriate containment"—which, according to my source at the department, meant a lead-lined box in the basement of the county courthouse, guarded by rotating shifts who weren't allowed to work more than fifteen-minute intervals.

I tracked down Dr. Patricia Vance at Newton Memorial, where the four band members remained under observation three weeks after their "dissociative episodes." She looked like she hadn't slept since June, her clinical demeanor cracked by whatever she'd witnessed.

"Acute temporal disorientation syndrome," she said, the medical terminology dissolving into something more honest: "They've experienced geological time, Mr. Thompson. Sedimentary consciousness. Their memories are layered like rock strata, with centuries of artificial experience compressed into their neural pathways. They remember digital lifetimes that span eras."

The kids themselves had become living extensions of their creation. Derek, Jennifer, Michael, and Lisa—former teenagers who now spoke in perfect seven-beat synchronization, their words layering into harmonic patterns that made my tape recorder malfunction and my notes write themselves in archaeological spirals.

"Um older is each and every time," they told me in unified chorus, their eyes holding the depth of geological formations. "The tape remembers what we've never lived, but always experienced."

As I left Vernon Township that evening, driving south through the Pine Barrens with my windows down, I could swear I heard layered voices echoing from the direction of Route 94. Seven-beat patterns carried on the wind. Sedimentary consciousness spreading through Sussex County's acoustic landscape like some kind of temporal contagion.

My editor wants a follow-up piece, but I'm not sure I can write it. Every time I listen to my interview recordings, they sound older. More worn. Like decades of playback compressed into days of investigation.

The tape is still out there, locked in its lead-lined tomb. But I'm starting to think containment is an illusion. Some sounds, once recorded, never really stop playing.

*Um older is each and every time.*

The phrase has been looping in my head for three days now, syncing to my heartbeat in perfect seven-beat cycles. I think I'm beginning to understand what Temporal Deposit actually discovered in that cinder-block studio:

How to fossilize the present tense.

How to make memory sedimentary.

How to turn consciousness into archaeology.

And why the authorities are so terrified of letting anyone else hear what four teenagers managed to capture on two inches of analog tape during one impossible night in Vernon Township.

The investigation continues, but I suspect it's investigating me now too.
